title: 113_hr5886
content: The Act is titled the "African Elephant Conservation and Legal Ivory Possession Act of 2014" and references the African Elephant Conservation Act. It also includes a limited exemption for certain African elephant ivory. Section 2203 (16 U.S.C. 4223) is amended to include an exemption for the importation and exportation of raw or worked ivory for museum purposes, without requiring permission from the Secretary. The amendment to Section 2203 (16 U.S.C. 4223) allows for the display of ivory in foreign museums or its return to foreign lenders, exempts raw or worked ivory lawfully importable into the US before February 24, 2014, and allows possession of worked ivory previously lawful in the US. SEC. 4. PLACEMENT OF UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICER IN EACH AFRICAN ELEPHANT RANGE COUNTRY. The Secretary, in coordination with the Secretary of State, may station one United States Fish and Wildlife Service law enforcement officer in the primary United States diplomatic or consular post in each African country with a significant population of African elephants to assist in their protection and apprehend individuals involved in illegal killing. SEC. 5 amends the African Elephant Conservation Act to require the Secretary of the Interior to certify to the President if a country is a significant point for illegal ivory trade. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of elephant ivory. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of African elephant ivory, allowing for the possession, sale, and transportation of lawfully imported or crafted ivory in the United States without prohibition. SEC. 7 addresses the importation of sport-hunted African elephant trophies, allowing citizens or legal residents of the United States to import trophies from countries with elephants on Appendix II of CITES. This does not affect the Secretary's duties under CITES or the Endangered Species Act. SEC. 8 of the African Elephant Conservation Act prioritizes financial assistance for projects in ivory producing countries aimed at anti-poaching efforts. Additionally, the Act is reauthorized for the years 2015 through 2019.
